body_text.text: Since the 18th century industrial revolution, the concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) has risen from 280 ppm to 400 ppm, of which about one-third was absorbed by the ocean (Martin and Gattuso, 2009; Peck et al., 2018) . The definition of ocean acidification (OA) was firstly proposed by Caldeira and Wickett in 2003 , which demonstrated that the absorption of CO might lower the pH value of the ocean and alter the seawater carbonate system (Caldeira and Wickett, 2003) . Recently, a decrease of 0.1 units ocean pH value has been observed and the value would be 0.3-0.4 at the end of this century (Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007) . In 2300, a pH reduction of 0.7 units is estimated to be caused by the continued release of CO 2 , and the speed of pH reduction will exceed any experienced in the past 300 million years (Hönisch et al., 2012) . OA is a new global environmental problem associated with global warming, which might impose tremendous impact on the marine ecosystem and marine organisms.

A number of recent studies have confirmed the adverse effects of OA on marine organisms, especially marine calcifiers, such as marine bivalves (Fabry, 2008; Ridgwell and Schmidt, 2010; Pan et al., 2015; Leung et al., 2017; Xu et al., 2019) . With the vital roles in marine and terrestrial ecosystems and major effects on humans mainly as food sources, many bivalves have been used as models to study the physiological response and adaptation mechanisms to OA. Most of the studies focused on collecting the negative effects of OA on calcification, growth, development, energy metabolism, acid-base regulation, immunological response and behaviors (Gazeau et al., 2013; Gobler and Talmage, 2013; Navarro et al., 2013; Parker et al., 2013; Kroeker et al., 2014; Liu et al., 2016) . The knowledge of the physiological mechanisms underlying these effects is important to understand the vulnerability of marine calcifiers to OA (Hofmann et al., 2008; Todgham and Hofmann, 2009; Li et al., 2016a) . At molecular level and cellular level, the involved genes and signal transduction pathways are the key drivers that determine whether these marine organisms could adapt to OA or compensate the deleterious impacts (Dineshram et al., 2015) . It is fundamental to identify these genes and characterize the pathways to understand the mechanism involved in the physiological response and adaptation of marine bivalves to OA. Previous mantle tissue transcriptome analysis demonstrated that energy, protein metabolism and shell matrix related genes (F-ATPase, hexokinase, elongation factor alpha, chitinase and tyrosinase) might contribute to the acclimation to elevated seawater pCO (Hüning et al., 2012) . In juvenile corals, it was found that the up-regulation of heat shock protein and Bcl-2 genes mediated the acclimation (Moya et al., 2015) . The results provide valuable information for the further investigation about the molecular basis of physiological response to ocean acidification.

The direct effects of OA are not only the decline of seawater pH value but also the alternation of chemistry of the seawater-carbonate system, such as dissolved inorganic carbon (the sum of the solution concentrations of CO , H 2 CO 3 , HCO − , CO 3 2− ) and saturation state of aragonite and calcite (Feely et al., 2004; Orr et al., 2005; Feely et al., 2012) . These changes would further affect the physiological status of marine organisms, such as the increase of calcium concentration in hemolymph partially from CaCO 3 shell dissolution for bivalves. The intracellular HCO 3 − and Ca 2+ of Patella vulgate increased significantly after shortterm exposure to elevated CO 2 (pH 8.2 and pH 7.6) (Marchant et al., 2010) . While the intracellular Ca 2+ in C. gigas was significantly lower than that in the control group after 7-day CO 2 exposure treatment at pH 7.5 (Wang et al., 2017a) . Intracellular calcium not only serves as a participant in various biological activities like metabolism regulation, biomineralization but a ubiquitous second messenger to regulate signal transduction within or between cells (Clapham, 2007; Zheng et al., 2015) . The changes of intracellular calcium to a number of stimuli and its involvement in signal transduction during stresses acclimation have been widely investigated and illustrated in plants (Yang et al., 2009; Cheval et al., 2013; Chen et al., 2015) . While the changes of intracellular calcium and the regulation mechanisms of calcium signal in marine animals in response to OA remain largely unknown. There are a series of reports about the differentially expressed genes (DEGs) or proteins related to calcium homeostasis, ion transport, signal transduction, and calcification process. For example, calcium transport ATPase (SERCA), calmodulin (CaM), calmodulin-like protein (CaML), calreticulin (CRT) and sodium/calcium exchanger (NCX) were found to be up-regulated after OA exposure, which led to the decrease of free calcium content in mantle cells of pearl oyster Pinctada fucata and further influenced biomineralization (Li et al., 2016a) . The upregulation of calcium-binding proteins (CBPs) such as calmodulin and cadherin was also reported in oyster larvae in response to OA at pH 7.6 (Dineshram et al., 2015) . These results demonstrated that various calcium signal pathways might jointly coordinate the responses to OA in marine organisms. Pacific oyster (Crassostrea gigas) is one of the most widely cultured species in the second largest animal phylum Mollusca (Kocot et al., 2011) and also an important marine calcifier and ecosystem engineer in the marine environment. Oysters are regarded as model organisms for biomonitoring and investigation of marine environmental stress. In the past decades, the large fluctuations in seawater pH along the coast imposed great threaten on the aquaculture of oyster and the maintenance of oyster reef ecosystem. Although negative effects of OA on the physiological responses of marine calcifers, including Pacific oyster, have been widely demonstrated, it remains largely unknown how Pacific oyster can adapt or acclimate to OA. It is of critical importance to explore the possible living strategy of Pacific oyster under OA. The recently released genome sequences of C. gigas (Zhang et al., 2012) provided solid support for transcriptome-wide analyses of the molecular mechanism in response to OA. In the present study, short-term (7 days) and long-term (60 days) seawater acidification were conducted with the objectives to examine the transcriptional changes of C. gigas under seawater acidification and reveal the potential molecular mechanisms of the physiological responses to OA in marine bivalves.

Oysters C. gigas (about 13.0 cm in shell length) were collected from a local farm in Qingdao, China. They were pre-acclimatized in normal aerated seawater at 15°C for two weeks before processing. All experiments were conducted with approval from Experimental Animal Ethics Committee, Institute of Oceanology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China.

The experiments were conducted in 100-L tanks continuously bubbled with the ambient air or air-CO 2 mixtures to control the pH value and dissolved oxygen, and the temperature was monitored at 15°C. Two pH values were used in the present study which were 8.10 (representing the present pH value) and 7.50 (representing future pH value). The pH value was controlled using an acidometer (AiKB, Qingdao, China) by controlling the bubbling of CO 2 . Sixty oysters were randomly divided into three groups, 20 oysters were kept in normal seawater of pH 8.10 for 60 days (blank group). Another 20 oysters were kept in seawater of pH 8.10 for 53 days, then transferred to the seawater of pH 7.50 and kept for 7 days (named as short group), and the last 20 were kept in the seawater of pH 7.50 for days (named as long group). The water was changed every other day using pre-bubbled seawater to ensure adequate water quality and the temperature and salinity were monitored to be 15°C and 33.0 psu, respectively. The measured parameters were shown in Table 1 . The oysters were fed with spirulina powder (Trans-Ocean Trading Co., LTD, Qingdao, China) every other day.

The hemolymphs were collected from posterior adductor muscle sinus of oysters from each group and then centrifuged at 1000g, 4°C for 10 min to harvest the hemocytes according to previous study (Sun et al., 2016) . The hemocytes were immediately stored at −80°C after addition of 0.5 mL Trizol reagent (Invitrogen) for subsequent RNA extraction and cDNA library construction. The serum was collected to determinate the H 2 O 2 and calcium content. Hemolymphs from six oysters were pooled together as one sample and three were three replicates for each experiment.

Thirty oysters were used for the CaCl 2 and EGTA exposure experiments. Ten oysters were cultured in the seawater supplemented with 2.5 mM CaCl 2 (Named as CaCl 2 group), another ten oysters were cultured in the seawater supplemented with 2.5 mM EGTA (Named as EGTA group), and the last ten oysters cultured in the normal seawater were employed as negative control (Named as control group). The hemocytes were collected at 48 h after exposure to determine intracellular Ca 2+ and ROS level by FACScan flow cytometry, and gene expression by RT-PCR analysis.

Total RNA was extracted using the Trizol-chloroform extraction method. The total RNA was quantified and checked for the integrity with Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer (Agilent Technologies). Total mRNA was isolated using Dynabeads® mRNA DIRECT™ Micro Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The isolated mRNA was converted into cDNA using the Ion Total RNA-Seq Kit v2 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) and the obtained cDNA was used for whole transcriptome library preparation using Ion PI Hi-Q OT2 200 Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). Finally, the constructed libraries were sequenced on the Ion OneTouch™ 2 System (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) using the Ion PI™ Sequencing 200 Kit v3 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The raw sequencing reads were submitted to NCBI Short Read Archive under the accession number of PRJNA637240.
body_text.section: Construction and sequencing of cDNA library

body_text.text: In the present study, nine transcriptome fragment libraries were constructed from the hemocytes of oyster in the blank, short-and long-term groups (three repeats for each group), and they were sequenced to the saturated level by Ion Proton™ System to compare the expression abundances and difference of transcripts. Fastx-Toolkit pipeline (http://hannonlab.cshl.edu/fastx_toolkit/index. html) was used to process the raw reads obtained from Ion Proton™ System to evaluate sequencing quality, remove low-quality reads, adaptor sequences, poly-N and known non-coding RNAs. The obtained clean reads were then mapped to the genome of oyster C. gigas (Zhang et al., 2012) by both Tophat2 and Bowtie2 software. After that, the gene expression abundances and difference between different groups were calculated using Cufflinks software based on the mapping results. Gene expression levels were calculated by fragments per kilo base of exon per million fragments mapped (FPKM). The variation of transcripts abundance was described by fold change value: log 2 (short/blank), log (long/blank). The functional annotation and gene ontology (GO) enrichment analysis of DEGs were conducted by Blast2GO. The GO distribution of all DEGs was analyzed at Web Gene Ontology Annotation Plot (WEGO) website (http://wego. genomics.org.cn/cgi-bin/wego/index.pl).

body_text.text: 2.5. cDNA synthesis and quantitative Real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) analysis Total RNA was extracted as mentioned above. The synthesis of cDNA was performed according to our previous study (Wang et al., 2016) using oligo (dT)-adaptor as primer (Table S1 ). The obtained cDNA mix was stored at −80°C and diluted 40-fold for qRT-PCR.
body_text.section: Data analysis and identification of DEGs

body_text.text: The mRNA expression levels of the DEGs were examined by SYBR Green fluorescent qRT-PCR. The C. gigas elongation factor (CgEF-1α) fragment was used as the endogenous control. The mRNA expression levels were analyzed by 2 −ΔΔCt method (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001 ). All the primers used for qRT-PCR were listed in Table S1 .

body_text.text: The hemolymphs of six oysters were mixed with pre-chilled anticoagulant (22 g L −1 sodium citrate, 8 g L −1 critic acid, 24.5 g L −1 glucose) at a ratio of 1:1 (v:v). The mixtures were then centrifuged (800 ×g, 4°C, 10 min) and the hemocytes were re-suspended in M-L-15 medium to a final concentration of 10 6 mL −1 . For intracellular calcium determination, hemocytes were incubated with Fluo-3 (5 μM) at room temperature for 20 min. After three times' washing, the hemocytes were detected by FACS Arial II flow cytometer and the relative Ca 2+ value was recorded as the median fluorescence intensity of 10,000 cells.

body_text.text: The upper liquid of hemolymphs after centrifugation was obtained as serum and stored at −80°C for subsequent determination. The calcium in serum was determined by the Inductively Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-AES) method (Perkin Elmer Optima 7300DV) at the Testing and Analysis center of Institute of Oceanology, Academy of Sciences.

body_text.text: The level of oxidative stress was determined by measuring the ROS level in hemocytes and H O 2 level in serum. The ROS level were detected according to our previous descriptions by incubating the hemocytes with 2′,7′-dichloro-fluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA) and measuring the median fluorescence intensity (Wang et al., 2016) . The H 2 O 2 level in serum was assayed using corresponding detection kits (Beyotime, China) according to the manufacturer's protocols.

body_text.text: Because CaMs was highly conserved in oyster C. gigas (Chen, 2017; Zhang et al., 2012) , a polyclonal antibody of a typical human CaM (CALM1) was employed for western blotting in the present study. The western blotting was performed according to the previous report (Wang et al., 2016) and the hemocytes protein samples were separated by SDS-PAGE followed by electrophoretical transfer on to a nitrocellulose membrane. After blocked with 5% defatted milk (dissolved in PBST), the membrane was incubated with polyclonal antibody (ABclonal, diluted 1:500 in blocking buffer) of a CaM (human CALM1, NP_001734.1) or β-tubulin at 4°C overnight. Then the membrane was washed and incubated with HRP labeled goat anti-rabbit IgG (ABclonal, diluted 1:500 in blocking buffer). After another three times of washing, the membrane was visualized by Thermo Scientific SuperSignal kit (Life Technologies) and developed with the chemiluminescence ECL western blotting system (Bio-Rad).

All the data were recorded as mean ± standard deviation, and analyzed by SPSS 16.0. The significant differences among groups were tested by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and multiple comparisons. Differences were considered significant at p b 0.05.

Nine transcriptomic fragment libraries of blank, short and long groups were successfully constructed and sequenced, with a total of 44,322,284 high-quality reads successfully mapped to oyster reference genome v9. The mapping rates were ranging from 51.0% to 68.5% for the nine libraries, and the unique mapping rates were ranging from 15.0% to 29.5%, respectively (Table S2 ). By gene assembling and expression abundance estimation with the method of FPKM, total 25,840 genes were identified in nine transcriptome libraries. The numbers of genes with FPKM N100 were 1702, 1663 and 1651 in the blank, short and long groups, respectively. There were 9399, 9208 and 8800 low abundant genes with FPKM b1, and 4294, 4110 and 3643 genes with FPKM = 0 in the blank, short and long groups, respectively (Table S3 ).
body_text.section: Overview of RNA sequencing and gene expression abundance estimation

body_text.text: There were 501 and 2728 significantly DEGs (p b 0.05) in the comparison of short versus blank (SVB) and long versus blank (LVB) ( Fig. S1 A) . In the Venn diagram of DEGs with the fold-change of gene FPKM value b0.5 or N2 (Fig. S1 B) , there were 185 genes in the SVB gene lists, including 80 genes that were significantly up-regulated and 105 genes that were significantly down-regulated (p b 0.05). While in the LVB gene lists, there were 988 DEGs, including 651 significantly up-regulated genes and 337 significantly down-regulated genes. There were 21 genes up-regulated in both lists and 56 genes downregulated in both lists. There were two genes that were up-regulated in the SVB gene list and down-regulated in the LVB gene list.

body_text.text: The GO term distributions of the differently expressed genes with the fold-change of gene FPKM value b0.5 or N2 were analyzed and the GO terms were summarized into three categories including biological process, molecular function and cellular component. The upregulated and down-regulated genes in the SVB group were enriched into 30 and 33 major GO terms, respectively (Fig. 1A, B ). The most abundant GO terms in the SVB lists were the metabolic process (GO:0008152), cellular process (GO:0009987), single-organism process (GO:0044699), binding (GO:0005488), catalytic activity (GO:0003824) and membrane (GO:0016020). For the LVB group, the up-regulated and down-regulated genes were enriched into 47 and 42 major GO terms (Fig. 1C, D ) and the most enriched GO terms were similar to that of the SVB group.
body_text.section: The GO enrichment analysis of DEGs in response to CO exposure

body_text.text: The set of transcripts up-regulated in the SVB group belonging to the category 'cellular components' comprised 21 genes, and 10 of them were enriched in the 'membrane GO:0016020' (Tables 2,  S4 ). For the LVB group, 236 up-regulated genes belonged to the category 'cellular components' and 125 of them were enriched in the 'membrane GO:0016020' (Tables 2, S4). More genes related to transportation such as sodium-coupled monocarboxylate transporter, amino acid transporter, solute carrier, sodium-driven chloride bicarbonate exchanger, zinc transporter, ATP-binding cassette transporters were up-regulated in the LVB group than that in the SVB group (Table S4) . A set of significantly differently expressed transcripts enriched in the category of heterocyclic compound binding (GO:1901363) were analyzed, and nine out of 38 genes were found to be significantly up-regulated, while 22 out of 39 genes were significantly down-regulated in the SVB group (Table 2) . The differently expressed genes were mainly involved in ATP or GTP binding (Table S5 ). In the LVB group, 112 out of 360 genes were significantly up-regulated and 67 out of 166 genes were significantly down-regulated (Table 2) . Most of the differently expressed genes could be identified as ATP or GTP binding and DNA or RNA binding (Table S5 ).
body_text.section: The GO enrichment analysis of DEGs in response to CO exposure

body_text.text: For the genes up-regulated in the LVB group, the calcium binding GO term (GO:0005509) was the most significantly enriched (Table S6 ). The differently expressed genes with the fold-change of FPKM value b0.5 or N2 in the short and long group were filtered through GO annotation of calcium binding (Table S7 ) and 73 calcium ion binding genes were selected for Hierarchical clustering analysis, and they were clustered into four distinct branches based on their FPKM values (Fig. 2) . Compared to the blank and short group, the expression levels of a large branch of calcium-binding proteins in the long group were significantly up-regulated (green box in Fig. 2) .
body_text.section: CO 2 exposure activated expression of calcium binding proteins and altered calcium and oxidative levels

body_text.text: The DEGs in the LVB group annotated as calcium binding were further analyzed to infer their potential roles in response to CO exposure (Table 3) . Extracellular calcium binding proteins with various domains including epidermal growth factor (EGF)-like domain, cadherin domain, carboxyl glutamic acid-rich domain, lectin domains, EF-hand domains, and intracellular buffers and sensors such as sarcoplasmic CBP (SCP), troponin C (TroC), calmodulin (CaM) were related to extracellular and intracellular calcium regulation. Calcium channel (CaC) and membrane associated transporters such as polycystin-2, voltage-dependent calcium channel type D subunit alpha-1 (VDCC), calcium-binding mitochondrial carrier protein (CMCP) and receptors such as metabotropic glutamate receptors (MgluR) were involved in calcium transportation and downstream signal transduction.
body_text.section: CO 2 exposure activated expression of calcium binding proteins and altered calcium and oxidative levels

body_text.text: The concentration of Ca 2+ in hemocytes (Fig. 3A ) and calcium content ( Fig. 3B ) in serum were evaluated. After 7 days' exposure to elevated CO 2 , the Ca 2+ concentration in hemocytes was much lower than that in the blank group and the fluorescence intensity of hemocytes decreased by 29.5% (p b 0.05). But after 60 days' exposure to elevated CO , the Ca 2+ concentration in hemocytes recovered to the blank level and the fluorescence intensity of hemocytes was 48.2% higher than that in the short group (p b 0.05). The calcium content in the serum increased from 350.6 mg L −1 in the blank group to 365.4 mg L −1 in the short group (p b 0.05) and 372.6 mg L −1 in the long group (p b 0.05). The ROS level in hemocytes ( Fig. 3C ) and H 2 O 2 production (Fig. 3D ) in serum were also determined after short-and long-term CO exposure. The levels of ROS and H O 2 production increased significantly after 7 days' exposure to elevated CO , which were 2.47-fold (p b 0.05) and 2.54-fold (p b 0.05) of the blank group, respectively. After long-term CO 2 exposure (60 d), the intracellular ROS level in hemocytes and H O 2 content in serum both decreased to the blank levels (p N 0.05).
body_text.section: CO 2 exposure activated expression of calcium binding proteins and altered calcium and oxidative levels

body_text.text: The mRNA expression levels of six calcium-binding genes (Selected from Table 3) in the hemocytes after CO exposure were examined (Fig. 4A) . The expression levels of CGI_10016652, CGI_10013668 and CGI_10013598 displayed an increasing trend in the short and long group (p b 0.05). There was no significant difference of relative expression levels of CGI_10025417 in the short and long group, but they were 5.59fold (p b 0.05) and 6.11-fold (p b 0.05) higher than that in the blank group, respectively. For the other two genes CGI_10006481 and CGI_10003007, there was no significant difference between the blank and short group, while their expression levels ascended to 7.15-fold and 4.20-fold in the long group (p b 0.05), respectively. The responses of the six genes to calcium-redundant and calcium-free environment were investigated (Fig. 4B ). Their expression levels increased significantly (p b 0.05) after CaCl 2 exposure, which were 2.55-fold, 4.51-fold, 4.08fold, 3.97-fold, 3.63-fold and 2.79-fold for CGI_10016652, CGI_10013668, CGI_10013598, CGI_10025417, CGI_10006481 and CGI_10003007, respectively. In contrast, the expression levels of CGI_10016652, CGI_10013668, CGI_10006481 and CGI_10003007 decreased significantly (p b 0.05) to 0.18-fold, 0.24-fold, 0.13-fold and 0.30-fold after EGTA exposure, respectively. The expression level of CGI_10013598 was significantly up-regulated (2.36-fold, p b 0.05) after EGTA exposure, which was still significantly lower than that of CaCl exposure group. No significant change was observed for the expression of CGI_10025417 after EGTA exposure. Meanwhile, increases of intracellular Ca 2+ and ROS level was also observed in hemocytes (p b 0.05) (Fig. S2) .
body_text.section: The response of calcium-binding genes and relevant signaling molecules

body_text.text: The responses of CaM and the possible signaling molecules were further explored (Fig. 4C) . The mRNA expression levels of another two calcium-binding genes annotated as CaM, CGI_10005633 and CGI_10027355, increased after short-and long-term CO exposure, and their relative expression levels in the short and long group were 0.81-fold (p N 0.05) and 2.67-fold (p b 0.05), 1.41-fold (p b 0.05) and 2.37-fold (p b 0.05) of that in the blank group (Fig. 4C1) , respectively. The results were consistent with the calculated FPKM value in the transcriptomic data. Western blotting of CaM revealed three distinct bands of about 15 kD, 35 kD and 70 kD in hemocytes (Fig. 4C2) . The three bands should be EKC20231, EKC24243 and EKC20234 (GenBank accession number) or their superfamily members according to the alignment between protein sequences of CALM1 and oyster sequences (percentage identity of alignment N90%). The 35 kD band was much thicker than the other two bands and it was observed in all the three groups. The relative protein expression level displayed an increasing trend after 7-day (1.89-fold) and 60-day CO 2 exposure (6.88-fold) (Fig. 4C2 b) . The 70 kD band was revealed after longer exposure time with chemiluminescence ECL western blotting system and the count value of this band also increased under acidification than that in the blank group (1.27-fold and 2.10-fold in the short and long group, respectively) (Fig. 4C2 a) . The 15 kD band, however, was mainly detected in the long group and the count values of this band was 5.07-fold and 5.63-fold of that in the blank group and the short group (Fig. 4C2 c) , respectively. NOS has been proved to be the downstream target of Ca 2+ -CaM signal pathway and there is only one NOS identified in oyster (Jiang et al., 2016) . The relative expression level of NOS (CGI_10014826) after CO 2 exposure was investigated by RT-PCR (Fig. 4C3 ). In the short and long group, it was 1.16-fold (p N 0.05) and 3.27-fold (p b 0.05) of that in the blank group, respectively.

body_text.text: There is growing evidence that some species have the ability to rapidly acclimate to CO exposure, constituting a glimmer of hope to the adaptation of marine organisms to OA (Kelly and Hofmann, 2013; Wong et al., 2018; Migliaccio et al., 2019; Griffiths et al., 2019) . However, it still remains unclear for most marine organisms whether they can adapt or acclimate to OA and the underlying mechanisms are still not well understood. In the present study, the transcriptome analysis of hemocytes from the oyster C. gigas after 7-day and 60-day CO exposure was conducted in order to find the expression alternations resulted from shortand long-term CO 2 exposure and offer fundamental new clues to cognize the mechanism of mollusk response or adaptation to OA. After oyster C. gigas was exposed to the elevated CO 2, significant enrichments of membrane (GO:0016020) and binding (GO:0005488) were observed, which were the most abundant categories in both the SVB and LVB groups (Fig. 1) . This finding suggested that the enhanced activities involved in the membrane, binding such as ion exchange, acid-base regulation emerged as the principal transcriptome responses of adult C. gigas to CO 2 stress. The result was conformed to the previous reports that the genes related to ion-transport were up-regulated in coral (Vidal-Dupiol et al., 2013) , pearl oyster (Li et al., 2016a) , and sea urchin (Evans et al., 2013) . The regulation of these genes was also correlated with physiological changes after short-and long-term CO 2 exposure. For example, intracellular HCO 3 − and Ca 2+ in limpet (Patella vulgata) increased (Marchant et al., 2010) after 5-day CO 2 exposure. The increase of intracellular HCO 3 − was also observed in ephalopod (Sepia officinalis) at h after CO 2 exposure (Gutowska et al., 2010) and oyster (C. gigas) after 22-day CO 2 exposure (Lannig et al., 2010) .

In the present study, the variations of the intracellular calcium concentration and extracellular calcium content (calcium content in serum) were observed, which could also support these transcriptional changes. It has been documented that the active energy metabolism of marine and estuarine mollusks is always accompanied with ion transportation (Lannig et al., 2010; Ivanina et al., 2013; Moya et al., 2016) . A set of significantly differently expressed genes were enriched in the category heterocyclic compound binding (GO:1901363) in both the SVB and LVB gene lists (Tables 2, S5 ). The GO annotation of these DEGs indicated that they were mainly involved in ATP or GTP binding, implying the metabolic regulation under CO 2 exposure. It was previously reported that ATP content in the gill tissue of Pacific oyster increased significantly after two-week CO 2 exposure (pH 7.5), which could support this hypothesis (Wang et al., 2017b) . For other bivalve mollusks exposed to the elevated CO , there were also increases in standard metabolic rate which would increase the ATP levels (Parker et al., 2013) . Under long-term exposure to OA, metabolic depression was observed in pearl oyster, which was considered to mitigate the effects of seawater acidification (Li et al., 2016a) . The present transcriptome data illustrated that the responses of C. gigas to short-and long-term CO exposure shared common mechanisms in metabolism, membrane-associated transportation, and binding processes. Despite the common mechanisms, it should be noticed that the number of DEGs in LVB group (2728) was much higher than that in SVB group (501). The GO enrichment analysis showed that there were more enriched GO terms assigned to behavior, biological adhesion, cellular component organization or biogenesis, development process, growth, locomotion, reproduction, reproductive process and rhythmic process for the up-regulated genes, and immune system for the downregulated genes in the LVB group (Fig. 1) . Similarly, more differentially expressed unigenes were also identified from oyster (Pinctada fucata) mantle tissue after 60-day CO exposure than 72-h CO 2 exposure (Li et al., 2016a; Li et al., 2016b) . The results suggested that short-term CO 2 exposure might induce physiological changes but not the mRNA expression levels of most transporters, while long-term CO exposure could stimulate the transcription of transporter mRNA to facilitate the adaptation of oyster to increased CO level. The enhanced transcription regulation might be supported by the differently expressed genes in the LVB group, which were assigned into heterocyclic compound binding category (GO:1901363) (Table S5 ). More DEGs related to DNA or RNA binding were differentially expressed in the LVB group, such as DNA polymerase III PolC-type, Musashi family of RNA-binding proteins, zinc finger protein, transcription factors and etc. DNA polymerase III PolCtype was found to be involved in multiple enzymatic pathways, including DNA replication, homologous recombination and mismatch repair (Sarangi et al., 2015) . The up-regulation of these genes indicated that long-term CO 2 exposure was associated with changes of DNA replication process. The Musashi family of RNA-binding proteins has been shown to control translation and regulate multiple stem cell populations (Sutherland et al., 2013) . It was found that the percentages of large hyalinocytes and granulocytes in pearl oyster (Pinctada fucata) increased after CO exposure (Ellis et al., 2015) . These results suggested that the increased expression of RNA-binding protein Musashi-like protein Rbp6 might contribute to the translation process and the regeneration, differentiation and maturation of hemocytes. A series of transcription regulators, such as zinc finger protein, homeobox protein caupolican, serine/threonine-protein phosphatase 1 were also upregulated, providing more evidences to the stimulated transcription process of the LVB group. Therefore, these altered replication, transcription and translation processes might provide a plausible explanation for responses of oyster to long-term CO 2 exposure.

Calcium ion serves as a ubiquitous second messenger and impacts nearly all aspects of life activities (Clapham, 2007) . Marine organisms must have precise regulation mechanisms to ascertain calcium homeostasis. In the present study, the extracellular calcium content (calcium content in serum) displayed an increasing trend with the CO exposure time (Fig. 3B) . This result corresponded with the previous report in marine mussels that the Ca 2+ in hemolymph increased after long-term moderate hypercapnia treatment (Michaelidis et al., 2005) . The intracellular calcium ion concentration, however, decreased significantly after short-term CO 2 exposure and then recovered to the comparable level of the blank group after long-term exposure (Fig. 3A ), suggesting that there might exist mechanism for oysters to fully compensate the changes of intracellular Ca 2+ after 60 days' CO exposure. Previous studies indicated that calcium was essential for production of ROS (Camello- Almaraz et al., 2006; Gorlach et al., 2015) , and the improved cellular calcium homeostasis could reduce ROS production in both vertebrates (Hu et al., 2017) and invertebrates like the rotifer Brachionus plicatilis (Zhang et al., 2016) . In the present study, the ROS level in oyster hemocytes and H 2 O 2 content in the serum both increased significantly after CO exposure of seven days compared to that in the blank group (p b 0.05). However, they decreased and recovered to the normal level after long-term CO 2 exposure, a change corresponding to the variation of intracellular calcium concentration. The results suggested the cross-talk between intracellular calcium and ROS level under CO exposure. Such cross-talk has been widely reported that Ca 2+ controls ROS production which in turn regulate Ca 2+ by activating Ca 2+ channels (Mazars et al., 2010) . Collectively, these results demonstrated that oysters could fully compensate the calcium and ROS variation after long-term CO 2 exposure, which might be crucial for the homeostasis and survival of the living marine animals from the sensitive environment as well as OA. The process of Ca 2+ homeostasis represents precise control and involves the engagement of a series of components of the Ca 2+ regulatory toolkit including Ca 2+ channels, Ca 2+ buffers, Ca 2+ sensors and receptors in the plasma membrane and organelles (Schwaller, 2012) . In the present study, the significantly enriched calcium binding GO term (GO:0005509) (Table S6 ) and the up-regulation of a series of CBPs were observed in the LVB group, which supported the proposal of calcium compensation in response to CO 2 exposure (Fig. 2, Table 3 ). Based on the differently expressed CBPs identified in the present study, a calcium regulatory toolkit in oyster hemocytes was further proposed to govern the calcium compensation after long-term CO exposure (Fig. 5) . The membrane associated transporters such as polycystin-2 and voltage-dependent calcium channel type D subunit alpha-1 were up-regulated significantly after 60-day CO 2 exposure to balance the calcium ion concentration among the extracellular and intracellular fluids. The similar results about the increased expression of voltage-dependent calcium channel were reported in sea urchin (Evans et al., 2013) and pearl oyster (Li et al., 2016b) under OA. A series of intracellular calcium buffers or sensors including Troponin C (Tro C), CaM and cadherin were induced after CO 2 exposure (Table 3 ). Tro C works as a medium for calcium shuttling from cytoplasm to sarcoplasmic reticulum facilitated by reported sarcoplasmic calcium-binding protein (SCB) (Yáñez et al., 2012) . CaM or CaM-like proteins are major calcium-binding messenger proteins and also fast calcium buffers that participate in transcellular transport step (Perry, 1997; Porta et al., 1996) . They can bind and regulate a number of different protein targets and thereby affect different cellular processes (Clapham, 2007; Li et al., 2014; Yang et al., 2014) . Cadherins can act as Ca 2+ sensors in response to the fluctuations of external Ca 2+ and participate in cell-cell adhesion and communication (Aguilar-Camacho and McCormack, 2017; Timmins-Schiffman et al., 2019) . The compensation in intracellular Ca 2 + may be mediated by release from or sequestration into organelles, mainly sarcoplasmic/endoplasmic reticulum (ER). The up-regulation of two extracellular CBPs (ECBPs)-MgluRs (Table 3 ) might contribute to Ca 2+ compensation through coupling to phospholipase C (PLC), inositol (1,4,5) triphosphate receptor (IP R), which could mediate the release of Ca 2+ from ER (Takahashi et al., 1996; Perovic et al., 1999) . In the present study, a series of extracellular CBPs (ECBPs) including proteins with EGF-like domain, cadherin domain, carboxyl glutamic acidrich domain, lectin domains and EF-hand domains were also found to be significantly up-regulated in the LVB group (Table 3) . In vertebrate, ECBPs participate in modulating various cellular functions such as Ca + transport, Ca 2+ homeostasis, cell-matrix interactions, cell-cell interactions, and receptor-ligand interactions (Yáñez et al., 2012) . EGF-like domain containing CBPs (EGF-CBPs) could bind Ca 2+ and induce protein-protein interactions, receptor-ligand interactions (Rao et al., 1995) . The C-type mannose receptor and macrophage mannose receptor belonging to lectin domains containing CBPs (Lec-CBPs) are important pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) and participate in the activation of the innate immune system or the defense repertoire of oyster (Song et al., 2010) . As there were no obvious signs of injury or infection of oyster after long-term CO 2 exposure, it could be surmised that the increase of extracellular calcium might directly induce the upregulation of these PRRs, representing a strategy to enhance survival from OA. Taken together, it was suspected that oysters could issue compensation mechanism, such as up-regulation of genes related to replication, transcription and translation processes and calcium binding to acclimatize themselves to acidification environment, although they underwent initial disruption of calcium concentration and oxidization stress after short-term CO 2 exposure.

In order to validate the transcriptomic variations of Ca 2+ regulatory toolkit, six CBPs belonging to different protein families (Table 3) were selected for the qRT-PCR analysis. The results (Fig. 4A) agreed well with the RNA-seq data, which further confirmed the increasing trend of CBP transcripts after CO 2 exposure. To investigate whether the increases of CBP transcripts were the general cellular responses to elevated serum calcium, the transcripts of these six CBPs were detected in hemocytes of the oysters exposed to EGTA and CaCl (Pinto et al., 2010) . The transcripts of all the six genes arose to significantly higher levels (p b 0.05) after CaCl exposure than that after EGTA exposure (Fig. 4B ), revealing that they were important elements of the Ca 2+ homeostasis control machinery against elevated serum calcium. In addition, increases of intracellular calcium level and ROS level were detected in both CaCl and EGTA group (Fig. S2) , confirming the interplay between calcium homeostasis and redox reaction in response to the stressed environment. It was suggested that the induction of CBPs could be an effective strategy of oysters to maintain calcium homeostasis and adaption to the increasing calcium in serum after long-term CO 2 exposure.

Calcium-CaM pathway plays crucial roles in cell signaling and participates in the activation of many proteins such as nitric oxide synthase, phosphodiesterases and cytoskeletal proteins (Dineshram et al., 2015; Li et al., 2016a) . The changes of CaMs at both mRNA and protein level were detected after CO exposure. The two genes including a CaM (CGI_10005633) and a CaM-like (CGI_10027355) displayed an upregulation trend after CO 2 exposure (Fig. 4C1 ), indicating CaM in oysters could be induced by seawater acidification, which was similar to those in other marine organisms (Dineshram et al., 2015; Li et al., 2016a; Cao et al., 2018) . The selected two genes displayed different expression pattern after short-and long-term CO exposure (Fig. 4C1) , in which CaM (CGI_10005633) was only significantly up-regulated in the LVB group and CaM-like (CGI_10027355) was up-regulated in both groups. Moreover, three distinct bands about 15 kD, 35 kD and 70 kD were identified in oyster hemocytes (Fig. 4C2 ) by using the polyclonal antibody of a typical human CaM CALM1 (Chen, 2017) . The 35 kD and the 70 kD band were identified in all the blank, short and long groups, and the count values displayed an increasing trend with the CO exposure time (Fig. 4C2) . While the 15 kD band was mainly detected in the long group. These results suggested that Ca 2+ -CaM signal pathway might play vital roles in the acclimation of oyster, among which different CaMs might execute diverse regulation function in the response to CO exposure. The mRNA transcripts of NOS, a downstream target of Ca 2+ -CaM signal pathway in oyster (Jiang et al., 2016) was further detected in the present study. The expression level of NOS was significantly up-regulated in the long group while remained unchanged in the short group (Fig. 4C3) . In animals, the activation of NOS is Ca 2+dependent and requires the binding of a Ca 2+ /CaM complex (Kone et al., 2003) . Its products NO can directly or indirectly modulate the activity of Ca 2+ channels or can rapidly react with O 2 • − (Mazars et al., 2010) . Compared with vertebrate, there is only one NOS in C. gigas (Jiang et al., 2016) , and the invertebrate NOS was reported to respond to a variety of environmental stresses such as heat, pollution, pH, bacteria and air exposure (Chen, 2017; Giovine et al., 2001; Jiang et al., 2013; Novas et al., 2007; Smith et al., 2000) . Therefore these altered mRNA/ protein expressions could provide an explanation for the reduced oxidative stresses to long-term CO 2 exposure. The up-regulation of NOS indicated that the Ca 2+ -CaM-NOS signal pathway might play important roles in sustaining internal homeostasis and enhancing the capability to deal with environmental fluctuations under long-term CO exposure.

In conclusion, CO exposure could induce significant changes at transcriptome level, and there were 501 and 2728 DEGs identified (p b 0.05) in SVB and LVB group, respectively. GO annotation of DEGs revealed that the responses of C. gigas to short-and long-term CO exposure shared common mechanisms in metabolism, membraneassociated transportation and binding processes. While the DEGs related DNA or RNA binding and calcium binding were more abundant in the LVB group. It was suggested that C. gigas might be able to compensate the effect of long-term CO exposure by regulating calcium homeostasis and stimulating the transcription of a series of calcium signal pathways. These compensation responses had a mutual interplay on the physiological status, such as the level of redox reaction, which offered oysters the capability to acclimatize the dynamically changing environment. The results provided valuable information to understand the molecular mechanism underlying the responses of Pacific oyster to the gradually acidified ocean and might have implications for predicting the possible living strategy of marine organisms to the effect of global climate changes.
